document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the genus Dziriblatta Chopard, 1936 (Blattodea, Ectobiidae, Ectobiinae) from North Africa, Spain, and the Macaronesian islands. I. The nine subgenera of the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the genus Dziriblatta Chopard, 1936 (Blattodea, Ectobiidae, Ectobiinae) from North Africa, Spain, and the Macaronesian islands. I. The nine subgenera of the genus

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Phyllodromica ( Lobolampra ) algerica :
Morales Agacino 1948: 342
; Princis 1971:1112 .

Aphlebia cazurroi : Bolívar 1887: 92
, t 4, fig. 8;
FINOT 1895: 87
, t 10, fig. 8.

Hololampra algerica, var. diademata:
Werner, 1931: 201
;
Werner 1932: 125
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. The only one among the species of the subgenus with strong differences in colouration between male (dark) and female (light), moreover well characterized by the unique structure of the male T7 gland.

Type material .
Syntypes : 1♀ , Algeria , Oran,
5.V.79
(Terminalia on slide: Bo 151) [Al 12]
;
1♀ , Oran . ( MNMS ).— Types of
Aphlebia cazurroi
:

.

Description. Size. Length of pronotum in male 2.11–2.27 (2.2 mean) mm, in female 2.43–2.59 (2.52 mean) mm.

Male structures. T7 with slightly produced latero-posterior corners ( Figs. 14D , 15 A–C). Glandular pit transversely oval, large, occupying at least half of the breadth of the tergite, partly bipartite by a longitudinal ridge arising from the posterior wall of the pit towards anteriorly. Pit opening (arrows in Figs. 15C ) anteriorly and posteriorly with a sharp edge, posterior wall steep, below the edge on both sides often with a shallow posterior excavation ( Figs. 15C , 16J); lateral walls gradually ascending and smoothly passing over to the tergite surface, opening, therefore, laterally not clearly delimited. Lobes of the pouch very long, considerably longer than T7, flat, strongly narrowed towards the tip, almost unsclerotized ( Fig. 15A ). Glandular pores present laterally on T2–5 ( Figs. 15D, E ), in very small numbers only or none on T6, none on T7 and following tergites.

Colouration. Male.
Thoracal nota with broad transparent margins, body otherwise almost completely dark brown, antennae and legs usually less dark, upper part of face often reddish ( Figs. 14 A–H, M). Among the numerous specimens studied one male was found with unusually light colouration (
Fig. 15I
); the structure of the T7 gland leaves no doubt about its affiliation to
Dz. algerica
. Female. Predominantly yellowish, thoracal nota with dispersed small dark spots of various size, tergites anteriorly with a brown transversal stripe, posteriorly with dark spots, often larger than on the nota, but never with larger dark markings, sternites dark with yellowish lateral margins (
Figs. 14I , N, O
).
Distribution. Northern Morocco and Algeria , from the Pays Rhomara (Rif) in Morocco as far as Algier in Algeria (Figs. 29, 32).

Remarks. The strong differences in the colouration between males and females have caused a long lasting confusion with
Dz. kroumiriensis
, which shows a similar sex specific colouration; but males as well as females of both species differ in quite a series of characters and allow a clear identification in both sexes.
